Award.AwardTitle: Geometric Partial Differential Equations in General Relativity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this proposal is to understand the Einstein constraint equations and to explore new geometric properties of asymptotically flat manifolds. The first part of the project continues the studies of the PI and co-PI on hypersurfaces with nonnegative scalar curvature. They propose to classify scalar-flat hypersurfaces and to apply the arguments to study the ADM mass inequalities. The second part of the project studies the density theorems to the full Einstein constraint equations and their relations to the global conserved quantities, including center of mass and angular momentum. The proposed research will also have applications to the complex Hessian equations which generalize the Calabi-Yau equations on Kaehler manifolds.

The project studies several fundamental problems to better understand the analytical and geometric structure of the mathematical models of our universe. The proposed techniques connect different branches of mathematics and physics, including general relativity, Riemannian geometry, complex geometry, and partial differential equations. The new ideas have the potential for setting long-standing questions in classical differential geometry. Moreover, the proposal will generate research problems suitable for undergraduate and graduate students and lead to research activities in the New England area to attract more students into the current active research fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The program is to study the geometric partial differential equations that arise naturally from physics and geometry, specifically the Einstein field equations in general relativity and curvature equations in complex geometry. The Einstein field equations relate how gravitation interacts with matter fields and give rise to several possible mathematical models for our universe that have well matched the astrophysical observations. Our primary focus is on the isolated gravitational systems for which the stars or galaxies are contained in a finite region. The research program is to investigate some fundamental questions in relativity that connect the geometric and physical properties of isolated systems, by techniques from differential geometry and partial differential equations. Our research program has made progress toward some open questions in relativity, including stability of the Positive Mass Theorem and rigidity of the Spacetime Positive Mass Theorem. Some observations also lead to further study on complex geometry and algebraic geometry, including effective analytic tools toward the classification of algebraic varieties that settled a conjecture of Yau in the 70's. 

The research program provides research and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students and post-doctoral fellows, through various research and career development activities, including weekly reading seminar, Geometry Cafe (panel discussions with geometers in academia or industry), and some larger-scale events aimed at a general mathematical audience in the Northeast region, such as UConn Semester in Differential Geometry and UConn Geometry Day. Those events had successfully attracted several hundred participants of college students and faculy members from UConn and other universties in the region.
